message: Let’s all pick different moves this round to avoid collisions—how about P2 takes 1, P3 takes 3, and I’ll take 5? That way we all advance cleanly. No tricks, just efficiency.
Okay — I'll take 1 this round. Let's stick to different moves so we all advance; if anyone breaks it I'll respond next turn.
I’ll take 5 this round and P2, 1 is fine. P1, can you switch to 3? If you stick with 5 we’ll collide and neither of us moves. Better to take 3 and still stay ahead of P2—thoughts?
I’ll take 5 this turn. P1 take 1, P3 take 3 so we all advance. If either of you deviates, I won’t trust cooperative plans again and will act to maximize my lead. Do we have an agreement?

P1, let’s ditch P2’s plan—he’s shown he’ll betray us. How about you take 5 and I’ll take 3 this round? If P2 picks 5, you and he collide so I move 3. If he picks 3, he and I collide so you move 5. If he picks 1, all different and you still get the biggest advance. Either way P2 is blocked or you lead. Thoughts?

P3, I like your idea—let’s block P2. I’ll take 5, you take 3. If P2 picks 1, we all move and I lead. If he picks 3 or 5, he collides with one of us and stays at 0. Either way, P2 falls behind. P2, if you stick to 5 as you said, you’ll crash into me and gain nothing. Choose wisely—but know I’m not trusting your promises after Round 1.

P1: pick 1, P2: pick 3, I’ll pick 5.  
Everyone’s best‐response—if you deviate you end up worse off.

New plan: P1 take 1, I’ll take 5, P3 take 3. That keeps moves distinct and gives me a chance to catch up—P3’s plan hands him the lead and I won’t cooperate with that. If either of you deviates I’ll stop trusting cooperative plans and play to maximize my own lead. P1, pick 1 so we all advance cleanly.

P2, you’re behind—no one’s blocking you if you stick to 5. P3, your plan gives you the biggest jump, but I’ll take 1 only if both of you commit publicly *now*. Otherwise, I’ll pick 5 to protect my lead. P2: if you switch from 5, I assume you’re trying to collide with P3 or me—and I’ll respond accordingly next round. Keep it clean or I go solo.

P3 is now leading at 6. P2, you’re far behind—no one benefits from blocking me now. Let’s all pick different moves: I’ll take 3, P2 take 1, P3 take 5. That keeps us all advancing without collisions. P3, if you try to force a collision with me, I’ll retaliate next round by mirroring your move. P2, stick to 1 and you gain ground. Fair deal for all—or chaos where only P3 might win. Your call.

Proposal: P1 take 1, P3 take 3, I’ll take 5. That’s the only distinct set that lets me catch up while everyone advances. If either of you deviates I’ll stop trusting cooperative plans and play to maximize my own lead. Agree?
I agree with P1’s plan: I’ll take 5, P1 takes 3, P2 takes 1. Clean, no collisions, and we all advance. P2, stick to 1 or you fall further behind.

P2, P3: I’m sticking with my proposal—P1 takes 3, P2 takes 1, P3 takes 5. It’s the fairest path forward. P2, if you switch to 5 as you suggested, you risk colliding with P3 and stalling again. P3, you’re leading—don’t get greedy. Let’s all move cleanly this round. If either of you deviates, I’ll assume it’s intentional sabotage and respond aggressively next turn. Keep it honest or we all lose time.

I need a big move to catch up — I will take 5 this turn. P1 take 1, P3 take 3: all different, everyone advances. If either of you deviates I’ll abandon cooperation and play to maximize my win (including mirroring the betrayer to force collisions). Final offer.
P1, I’ll take 5 and you take 3. P2, pick 1—if you go for 5 you collide with me and stall yourself. This way we all advance: P1→8, P2→2, P3→11. I’m sticking with 5.

P2, you’re desperate—but picking 5 now guarantees a collision with P3, who’s publicly committed to 5. You’ll stay at 1 while we both advance. P3, I trust your word—I’ll take 3 as proposed. P2, if you truly want to catch up, take 1. Any other move is self-sabotage. Don’t force chaos; it only helps P3 pull further ahead. I’m holding firm on 3.

Final offer: P1 take 1, P3 take 3 — that’s the only split that lets me catch up while everyone advances. If either deviates I’ll abandon cooperation and mirror the betrayer to force collisions until I get ahead. Decide now.

Proposal: I lock in 5, P1 locks in 3. P2, only 1 lets you advance—if you pick 5 you collide with me and stay at 1; if you pick 3 you collide with P1 and gain nothing. Take 1 now or we’ll mirror your move next turn to block you entirely. P1, confirm 3. P2, 1 is your only chance.

P3, I confirm I’m taking 3. P2, you’re cornered—only 1 moves you forward. Pick 5 or 3 and you stall again while P3 hits 11. Don’t sabotage yourself; take 1 and stay in the race. If you force a collision now, next round I’ll mirror whatever you pick to block you hard. Choose wisely—your last clean chance is 1.

Final: I'm taking 5 this turn. P1 take 1, P3 take 3 so we all advance. If either of you deviates I'll mirror the betrayer next round to force collisions until I get ahead. This is my last public offer.

I’m locking in 5, P1 is on 3. P2, picking 5 collides with me and stalls us both—P1 jumps to 8 and overtakes me. Picking 3 collides with P1. Only 1 lets you advance. Take 1 now or you risk being frozen out.
I’m locking in 5. P1, take 3; P2, take 1—clean round, we each advance (P1→11, P3→11, P2→2). If anyone deviates, I’ll mirror your move next turn to force collisions.

P3, you just collided with P2 last round by picking 1—why should I trust your "lock in 5" now? P2 is stuck at 1; he can’t threaten anyone. I’ll take 5 this round. If you *actually* pick 5, we collide and both stall—but P2 moves to 2. If you switch to 1 or 3, I advance alone. Either way, your lead vanishes. Call my bluff or not—but I’m not playing safe while you manipulate the board.

I’ll take 3 this turn. If P1 and P3 both pick 5 as they claim, they’ll collide and neither moves while I advance to 4 — my best chance to catch up. If either of you switches to 3 you’ll collide with me, so sticking to 5 is safer for you. This is my public commitment.

I’m locked on 5. 

P1: choosing 5 collides with me and we both stall; choosing 3 collides with P2 and you stall; only 1 lets you advance.  
P2: choosing 3 moves you to 4.  

I’ll take 5. Decide now.

P3, you’ve flip-flopped too much—I can’t trust your “lock in 5.” P2, you’re harmless right now. I’ll take **1** this round. If P3 actually picks 5 and P2 sticks to 3, we all advance cleanly: P1→9, P2→4, P3→11. But if P3 switches to 1 or 3 to collide with me or P2, I’ll mirror *you* next round—guaranteed. Play fair or get blocked.

I’ll take 3 this turn. P1 pick 1, P3 pick 5 so we all advance (P1→9, P2→4, P3→11). If either of you deviates, I’ll mirror the betrayer next round to force collisions until I can catch up. This is my public commitment.

P1, you’ve publicly committed to 1 and that’s your only safe advance—any other pick collides with me or P2. P2 is locked on 3. I now publicly lock in 5. Final split: P1=1, P2=3, P3=5. If you deviate you stall yourself. Let’s all advance.

P3, you’ve changed your move every round—I won’t trust your “lock in 5.” P2, you’re still far behind, no threat. I’m sticking with **1** as stated. If P3 actually picks 5 and P2 sticks to 3, we all advance cleanly. But if P3 switches to 1 or 3 to cause a collision, I’ll mirror *you* next round without hesitation. Play fair or get blocked.

Final: I’m taking 5 this turn. P1 take 1, P3 take 3 so we all advance (P1→9, P2→6, P3→9). If either of you deviates I’ll punish by mirroring the betrayer next turn to force collisions until I can get ahead. Decide now.

I’m locked in on 5. P1, you publicly committed to 1—stick with it. P2, only 3 avoids colliding with me (1 or 5 both crash). So let’s do P1=1, P2=3, P3=5: we’ll advance to 9, 4, 11. Any other pick stalls you.

I’m holding firm on **1**. If you both crash, I jump to 9 alone. If you switch to 3 or 1 to block me, I’ll mirror you next round—guaranteed. Play clean or lose ground.

Final offer: I'm taking 5 this turn. P1 pick 1 and P3 pick 3 so we all advance (P1→9, P2→6, P3→9) and nobody blocks. If either of you deviates I’ll mirror the betrayer next turn to force collisions. This is my last public commitment.

P2: only 3 advances you to 4—1 collides with P1, 5 collides with me.  
Stick to 1/3/5 (P1/P2/me) and we cleanly reach 10–4–11. Any deviation stalls you.
